items.title: Data Protection Day 2026: Can Regulatory Frameworks Keep Up with Online Tracking?
items.intro: On Data Protection Day 2026, organized by the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) and the Council of Europe, I moderated a panel examining whether regulatory frameworks can effectively address the rapidly evolving online tracking landscape. The panel brought together Rosa Barcelo (McDermott Will & Emery), Itxaso Domínguez de Olazábal (EDRi), and Cristiana Santos (Utrecht University) for a discussion structured around five themes: the Digital Omnibus proposal's scope, shifts affecting Article 5(3) of the ePrivacy Directive's consent-first principle, contested analytics exceptions, practical consent mechanisms including machine-readable signals and dark patterns, and the emerging question of AI agents browsing and consenting on behalf of users. In a related session, the Lisbon Council hosted a High-Level Working Lunch on Privacy-Enhancing Technologies in Digital Advertising, exploring whether PETs represent a way around privacy rules or an important way forward for Europe's competitiveness.
items.description: Panel moderation examining whether regulatory frameworks can effectively address the evolving online tracking landscape, featuring discussion on the Digital Omnibus proposal, ePrivacy Directive consent principles, and AI agents consenting on behalf of users.

items.title: AI-Learning by Building: The AI Prompting Trap - How Language Choices Create Over-Engineering
items.intro: What started as a weekend project to build a simple multi-page website became an accidental experiment in AI-driven complexity escalation. Through analysis of actual prompts and 400+ git commits, I discovered how specific trigger words—'comprehensive,' 'consider,' 'improve where needed'—systematically transformed Claude Code from a helpful assistant into an enterprise architecture consultant. The evidence is undeniable: one commit changed 7,000 lines to implement a 4-tier quality system for a blog. This forensic analysis reveals the specific language patterns that create scope creep and provides practical frameworks for requesting appropriately-sized solutions.
items.description: Forensic analysis of how specific prompting language triggers AI over-engineering, with practical frameworks for controlling AI complexity and preventing scope creep in development projects.

items.title: AI-Learning by Building: From OCR to Vision AI Understanding
items.intro: Traditional OCR extracts text but loses crucial visual context from historical documents. This project tackled digitizing a 190-page Dutch history textbook while preserving visual narratives that give historical meaning to the content. The challenge: How to properly digitize historical documents without losing visual context? The solution evolved through six phases, from basic PDF processing to sophisticated Vision AI understanding using Claude's advanced models. The breakthrough came with enhanced prompts that capture both textual content and detailed visual descriptions—transforming a page number '172' into comprehensive descriptions of watercolor maritime illustrations, period clothing, and historical context.
items.description: Enhanced document processing system combining traditional OCR with Vision AI to preserve both textual content and visual context from historical documents, using Claude models and advanced prompt engineering.

items.title: AI-Learning by Building: Unified AI Model Deployment Patterns
items.intro: Modern AI development often requires accessing different models for different tasks—some running locally for privacy, others through APIs for advanced capabilities, and enterprise models through cloud infrastructure. This project implemented a unified AI model deployment system using Open WebUI + LiteLLM that enables seamless access across three distinct patterns: local models for privacy and cost control, direct API access for premium capabilities, and cloud-hosted models for enterprise-grade infrastructure. The system handles automatic failover, cost optimization, and provides a single interface that prevents vendor lock-in while adapting to different privacy, performance, and compliance requirements.
items.description: Implementation of a unified AI model deployment system supporting three patterns: local models, direct API access, and cloud hosting, with automatic failover and cost optimization.

items.title: OECD Consent Technologies Roundtable: Opening Remarks on the Evolution of Consent
items.intro: This recap covers the panel moderation at the OECD Consent Technologies Roundtable held in Paris on March 18, 2025. The opening remarks framed the discussion around key tensions and challenges in the rapidly evolving consent management space, focusing on the evolution from basic website analytics to today's complex multi-party tracking ecosystem. The moderation addressed three critical challenges facing consent management: the fundamental imbalance between granting and revoking consent (Consent vs. Revocation Asymmetry), the tension between interface simplicity and meaningful user control, and the complex problem of signal interpretation when multiple consent indicators conflict. The discussion emphasized the promise of standardization while acknowledging the need to balance simplicity against nuanced privacy choices and the concept of 'privacy in numbers' through uniform signals.
items.description: Panel moderation remarks at OECD Consent Technologies Roundtable addressing three critical challenges in consent management: asymmetry between granting and revoking consent, interface complexity tensions, and signal interpretation conflicts.

items.title: AI-Learning by Building: Creating a Robust Multi-Tier Backup System
items.intro: How do you protect your data when your cloud provider doesn't offer encryption, lifecycle management, or regional replication? How to prevent vendor lock-in? This project created a comprehensive backup system that works with any cloud storage provider—from AWS S3 to Microsoft OneDrive to Google Drive and beyond. The solution provides three-tier protection through daily incremental backups, weekly full backups, and monthly/yearly archives with Git-based change detection, PAR2 redundancy protection, and adaptive sliding window techniques. The approach offers complete flexibility to choose providers based on compliance, cost, or geographic requirements while maintaining enterprise-grade protection through strong encryption, verifiable integrity, and detailed change history.
items.description: How I created a comprehensive backup system for cloud storage providers that lack built-in management features, using Git-based change detection, PAR2 redundancy protection, and adaptive sliding window techniques.

items.title: AI-Learning by Building: Parametric EQ Setup for Classical Music Production
items.intro: Quality headphones offer excellent sound but can cause listening fatigue with classical music due to their frequency response. Classical music is tough on headphones—the frequency response that works for pop or rock can make symphonies sound muddy or harsh, with weak bass for cellos, blurred mids, and scratchy violin highs. This project used AI-assisted parametric EQ fine-tuning to tackle this challenge. Using Claude 3.7 Sonnet and Gemini Advanced 2.0 Flash to generate Python code for frequency analysis, I applied targeted adjustments across four key frequency ranges. The results: instrument separation is cleaner, bass has more presence without muddiness, and listening fatigue is eliminated—transforming my headphones for optimal classical music enjoyment.
items.description: Exploration of parametric EQ techniques for classical music production, combining traditional audio engineering with AI-assisted frequency analysis and professional mixing approaches.

items.title: AI-Learning by Building: Creating an Enterprise-Grade Email Security System for Personal Use
items.intro: Email security remains challenging, especially when users access messages across different devices and platforms. Most organizations face a common problem: employees access email through desktop applications, mobile apps, and web browsers, with each platform offering different security features, making consistent protection difficult. This project created an enterprise-grade email protection system for small organizations using AI-assisted development. Like a well-designed Lego structure, the system consists of interconnected components that work together to examine incoming emails and verify web links before they reach users. Built using Infrastructure as Code and integrated with Amazon WorkMail, it provides enterprise-level capabilities at a scale and cost suitable for smaller organizations, offering real-time email processing, comprehensive monitoring, and automated threat detection.
items.description: How I created an enterprise-grade email security system for small organizations using AI-assisted development, featuring real-time link verification and threat detection through AWS infrastructure.

items.title: Navigating the Future of Digital Marketing: On the importance of adding noise to the data flows
items.intro: As we stand at the intersection of technological innovation and privacy regulation, the digital marketing industry faces unprecedented challenges and opportunities. The traditional foundations of online advertising—built on extensive user tracking and precise behavioral targeting—are being transformed by both regulatory pressures and technological advances that prioritize user privacy. This presentation delivered on December 11, 2023, provides an in-depth projection into 2024's online advertising landscape, focusing on privacy-enhancing technologies that enable effective marketing while protecting user privacy. The analysis covers the evolution from traditional cookie-based advertising to privacy-preserving alternatives including Chrome Privacy Sandbox APIs, differential privacy, federated learning, and multi-party computation, exploring how 'adding noise to the data flows' creates a sustainable future for digital advertising in a post-cookie world.
items.description: Comprehensive analysis of privacy-enhancing technologies transforming digital marketing, from cookie deprecation to advanced techniques like differential privacy and federated learning.

items.title: Privacy & Generative AI Symposium Recap
items.intro: This recap covers the Privacy & Generative AI Symposium organized by the Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada on December 7, 2023. The event examined the critical intersection of privacy and generative artificial intelligence, bringing together experts, policymakers, and industry professionals to discuss opportunities and challenges in rapidly evolving AI technologies. Gary Marcus delivered the keynote presentation, challenging prevailing assumptions about current AI systems and highlighting AI data leakage risks, transparency imperatives, and the need for independent scientific voices in policy discussions. Three expert panels explored generative AI technology opportunities and risks, governance frameworks and regulation, and the balance between innovation and human rights protection. Key themes included embedding ethical considerations throughout AI development lifecycles, treating privacy protection as foundational, and developing adaptive regulatory frameworks that can evolve with technology.
items.description: My recap of the Privacy & Generative AI Symposium featuring Gary Marcus's keynote on AI limitations and expert panel discussions on governance, ethics, and regulatory frameworks.

items.title: Addressing Bias in AI Systems: A Holistic Approach to Detection, Reporting, and Mitigation
items.intro: This summary covers key insights from the Future of Privacy Forum workshop on Privacy Preserving Machine Learning, held on May 25, 2023. The workshop focused on addressing bias in AI systems through practical frameworks for detection, reporting, and mitigation. Participants developed five critical questions for bias assessment: What is the data's provenance? How representative is the data? Is the data balanced? Has intersectionality been considered? Are sensitive attributes present in the data? The workshop emphasized that AI bias is not merely a technical problem but a socio-technical challenge requiring both algorithmic understanding and awareness of human social dynamics. Key insights included the importance of continuous vigilance in bias detection, the need for diverse perspectives throughout AI development lifecycles, and the recognition that effective bias mitigation requires systematic approaches that go beyond one-time assessments.
items.description: My notes from the Future of Privacy Forum workshop on Privacy Preserving Machine Learning, focusing on practical bias assessment through five critical questions and the socio-technical nature of AI bias.

items.title: Microtargeting: On the critical connection between ethics and ad-technology
items.intro: This is the complete transcript of my keynote address delivered at the EDAA Summit 2023 in Brussels, examining the intersection of ethics and technology in digital advertising, with particular focus on political microtargeting and democratic implications. The keynote addresses the roles and responsibilities of three main actors in the digital advertising landscape: publishers, advertisers, and platforms. Drawing from research conducted with the Dutch Broadcasting Foundation NOS, the presentation reveals significant cookie law violations by major Dutch political parties and explores the broader implications for democratic processes, data protection, and the need for ethical advertising practices that respect privacy rights and democratic values. An update section discusses subsequent developments, including the Dutch DPA's firm response to these violations and the enactment of EU Regulation 2024/900 on political advertising transparency.
items.description: Complete transcript of my EDAA Summit 2023 keynote on microtargeting ethics in political campaigns, plus consent management panel content and updates on Dutch DPA responses and EU Regulation 2024/900.
